docs.snippet: IN terms of pure romance, probably no place exerts such a hold on the imagination of voyager and highlander alike as the Isle of Skye, the largest of the Inner Hebrides. The mystical island is forever linked to the lure of escape across the water ...
docs.lead_paragraph: IN terms of pure romance, probably no place exerts such a hold on the imagination of voyager and highlander alike as the Isle of Skye, the largest of the Inner Hebrides. The mystical island is forever linked to the lure of escape across the water and refuge, epitomized by the flight of Bonnie Prince Charlie in 1746 and the haunting Scottish ballad "Over the Sea to Skye." Ever since the days of the Viking hegemony in A.D. 800 -- and before, for that matter -- the only way to get here has been by boat. Never mind that the strait between Kyle of Lochalsh on the mainland and Kyleakin is disappointingly narrow, enough almost to yell across were it not for the howling wind. Tourists delight in pouring aboard the small ferry for the 10-minute ride, sometimes even singing: "Speed bonnie boat, like a bird on the wing."

headline.main: Over the Sea To Skye, On a Toll Bridge

docs.snippet: WHEN President Clinton designated 1.7 million acres of Utah red rock county as a national monument last month, he spoke of the need to preserve places of beauty and solitude. It was a familiar refrain; on Earth Day (April 22), Mr. Clinton said tha...
docs.lead_paragraph: WHEN President Clinton designated 1.7 million acres of Utah red rock county as a national monument last month, he spoke of the need to preserve places of beauty and solitude. It was a familiar refrain; on Earth Day (April 22), Mr. Clinton said that low-flying aircraft over national parks could ''mar the natural beauty of the parks and create significant noise problems as well.'' Before long, the Department of Transportation proposed regulations for reducing noise from sightseeing aircraft over Grand Canyon National Park, resulting in a shouting match between environmentalists and the air tour business. Public hearings were held on the rules in Las Vegas and Scottsdale, Ariz., and the Federal Aviation Administration is expected to issue final regulations by year's end.
docs.abstract: Article on Transportation Dept proposals for reducing noise from sightseeing aircraft over Grand Canyon National Park (M)

headline.main: Abuzz About Flights Over the Grand Canyon

docs.snippet: On the Campidoglio in Rome stands an empty pedestal, a forlorn marble stump making the square, which was designed by Michelangelo, into a kind of eye without a pupil.   In 1981, a statue of the philosopher-emperor Marcus Aurelius that had been put...
docs.lead_paragraph: On the Campidoglio in Rome stands an empty pedestal, a forlorn marble stump making the square, which was designed by Michelangelo, into a kind of eye without a pupil. In 1981, a statue of the philosopher-emperor Marcus Aurelius that had been put there in 1538 by Michelangelo was removed for restoration. In 1990, the statue was restored to the Campidoglio, not to its original pedestal, but to an air-conditioned glass box in the nearby Capitoline Museum. Since then, debate has raged about whether the emperor should remain in his glass cage, or be restored to the original base. Experts say that even clean rainwater would have a corrosive effect on the statue's 1,800-year-old bronze skin. Rome's polluted elements would be devastating, they say.

headline.main: Empty Pedestal in Rome Fuels Debate Over Statue

docs.snippet: BEFORE New Year's Day 1994, this cobbled city, cradled in a valley surrounded by a pine-rimmed sierra, was a regular stop on the itineraries of certain hardy  travelers.         In Mexico's southernmost state of Chiapas, San Cristobal is the cente...
docs.lead_paragraph: BEFORE New Year's Day 1994, this cobbled city, cradled in a valley surrounded by a pine-rimmed sierra, was a regular stop on the itineraries of certain hardy travelers. In Mexico's southernmost state of Chiapas, San Cristobal is the centerpoint of a constellation of Indian villages that display their resilient Maya traditions in the scarlet and indigo dress of the women, the men's ribboned sombreros and in raucous religious fiestas. Simple Spanish colonial inns provided unhurried lodging for backpackers, academics and other rugged tourists with modest budgets.

headline.main: Visitors Venturing Back To San Cristobal

docs.snippet: Robert Mugabe apparently used a diplomatic loophole to evade European Union sanctions that bar him from traveling to any of the union's member states....
docs.lead_paragraph: Zimbabwe's president, Robert G. Mugabe, arrived in Rome on Thursday to attend Pope John Paul II's funeral, apparently using a diplomatic loophole to evade European Union sanctions that ostensibly bar him from traveling to any of the union's member states. Mr. Mugabe was reported to have landed Thursday morning at Flumincino airport in Rome to join an array of heads of state for the pope's funeral. Zimbabwe's state radio said he had been joined by his government's higher education minister, Herbert Murerwa.
docs.abstract: Pres Robert G Mugabe of Zimbabwe arrives in Rome to attend Pope John Paul II's funeral, apparently using diplomatic loophole to evade European Union sanctions that ostensibly bar him from traveling to any of union's member states; Mugabe appears to have evaded travel ban because he is going to Vatican, which is not member of EU (M)

headline.main: President of Zimbabwe Arrives In Rome, Despite Ban on Travel

docs.snippet: LEAD: WHILE planning a recent hiking trip to New Zealand, I mulled the paradox of the Milford Track. The three-day trek from lake to sea is so renowned for its scenic glories that it's billed as ''the most beautiful walk in the world.'' But the Mi...
docs.lead_paragraph: LEAD: WHILE planning a recent hiking trip to New Zealand, I mulled the paradox of the Milford Track. The three-day trek from lake to sea is so renowned for its scenic glories that it's billed as ''the most beautiful walk in the world.'' But the Milford is also a popular tourist destination and is strictly controlled by the authorities.

byline.original: By DAVID NOLAND; DAVID NOLAND, who writes about sports and travel, has been on treks in Sikkim, Kenya and Tanzania. He lives in Mountainville, N.Y

docs.snippet: THE grandeur of the Great Pyramids of Giza may be best appreciated from afar -- from across the desert, perhaps on horseback. But to those drawn also by the labyrinthine mysteries within, there is bad news: One by one, their cramped passageways ar...
docs.lead_paragraph: THE grandeur of the Great Pyramids of Giza may be best appreciated from afar -- from across the desert, perhaps on horseback. But to those drawn also by the labyrinthine mysteries within, there is bad news: One by one, their cramped passageways are being closed, at least temporarily, to tourists. The latest of the Pyramids to be shut is Mycerinus (also known as Menkaure), the third and smallest of the behemoths on the outskirts of Cairo. Archeologists had discovered that the moisture exhaled by the mounting number of tourists exploring the poorly ventilated chambers had raised humidity to dangerous levels, despoiling the structure by causing crystallized salt to line the walls and beginning to blacken them with fungi. The danger, according to Zahi Hawass, the director of the Pyramids and one who would prefer that they all be closed to tourists permanently, is that the salt can begin to crack and irrevocably weaken the 4,500-year-old structures, which are among the oldest surviving left by man.
docs.abstract: Egypt closes Mycerinus, one of Great Pyramids of Giza, to tourists for repairs; acts after archeologists find that moisture exhaled by mounting number of tourists poses threat to structure; other nearby pyramids remain open; photo (M)

headline.main: A Third Pyramid Closes for Repairs
